awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Genetic network evolution in grass abscission zones
awd_abstract_narration:
Agriculture depends on plants that hold on to their seeds until harvest, yet wild plants need to drop their seeds, in a process known as shattering or abscission. Therefore, domestication in cereal crops such as wheat, rice, and corn was the result of human selection for spontaneous mutant plants that did not shatter. In a world facing rapid population growth and changing climates, it is crucial to understand the mechanism of shattering to be able to domesticate and improve new wild or less domesticated cereal crops, thereby diversifying food choices and improving agriculture in marginal environments. This project will examine the shattering process, which is controlled by a specialized set of cells known as an abscission zone (AZ). Cell development of the AZ will be compared in different cereal crops and their wild relatives, including pearl millet and sorghum, two economically valuable and drought tolerant cereals. The project aims to identify genes that are required for a functional AZ, and to understand how modification of these genes causes morphological differences in the AZ in different species. High school students, undergraduates and secondary school teachers will be involved in conducting the research. The research experience provided to secondary school teachers will be used to develop new lesson plans, and further impact next generation education in science. 

Gene regulatory networks are continually modified over evolutionary time, but the speed of modification and the nature of the changes are generally not known. This project addresses both the tempo and mode of change in the network controlling the abscission zone (AZ) in plants, a specialized cell layer that permits plants to drop seeds, fruits, petals or leaves. The AZ of three distantly related grass species (weedy rice, Brachypodium, and Setaria) is controlled by distinct sets of genes, suggesting rewiring of the underlying genetic network. This project will investigate the AZ networks among additional species in grass subfamily Panicoideae, including wild and cultivated pearl millet (Cenchrus americanus, closely related to Setaria) and sorghum (Sorghum bicolor), a more distant relative. Histology (using light and transmission electron microscopy) and gene expression patterns (RNA-seq) will be characterized at several stages of development. To determine whether the extensive rewiring comes from changes in cis-regulatory modules, the upstream and downstream regulators of two conserved transcription factors, YAB2/SH1 and MYB26, will be characterized in the genetically tractable species Setaria and Brachypodium, with a combination of mutant analysis, RNA-seq, DAP-seq and bioinformatics. To determine if the disparate early regulatory networks converge on a conserved late stage set of genetic interactions, transcriptomic, enzymatic, and cell wall changes will be evaluated right before and after abscission. Together, these data will determine how and how fast the gene network regulating AZ formation is remodeled over time. High school students and teachers will be involved in many aspects of plant phenotyping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Abscission, the controlled disarticulation of dispersal units that include the seed, is an essential part of a plant’s lifecycle. In dicots abscission follows a well-conserved genetic pathway, but abscission patterns in the grasses are less understood, especially as to whether there is conservation in both the mechanism of abscission and the genetic pathways controlling abscission. Spontaneous mutations in genes controlling abscission pathway have been the basis of domestication for all cereal crops, and a number of mutations in different genes in individual species have identified, but the evidence for conservation of an abscission pathway is equivocal. In previous work, we discovered both a diversity of abscission mechanisms and disarticulation modes in the grasses as well as an almost total lack of genetic conservation. That work was based on three widely phylogenetically separated species of Setaria, rice and Brachypodium, where only two transcription factors in the respective genetic pathways showed evidence of conservation.

In the present grant, we investigated the function of the two conserved genes, a myb transcription factor, myb26, and a YABBY transcription factor, SH1. We found in a CRISPR-generated knockout of SH1 in Setaria viridis, that there were significant changes in genetic pathways controlling auxin and ethylene signaling and in pathways associated with senescence and cell wall hydrolysis. However, we found no evidence of lignification in the abscission zone, unlike the abscission process in rice and in dicots.

Shattering in Setaria is also controlled by a second locus, apart from SH1. The second locus is extremely close to or overlies the ortholog of another known shattering locus, qSH1, identified as a major gene affecting shattering in rice. This gene, a BEL transcription factor has also been identified as controlling tiller number in barley. Attempts to unequivocally genetically refine the position of the locus were not successful, so we decided to directly knock down the qSH1 locus using CRISPR technology. We achieved several different knockout mutations, but differences were only seen in tiller number and number of spikelets relative to sterile branchlets, rather than in degree of shattering.

To further examine diversity in abscission patterns we examined Cenchrus americanus/C. violaceum (pearl millet and its wild ancestor), which is in the same clade of the panicoid grasses as Setaria italica/S. viridis (foxtail millet and its wild ancestor). However, we found the process to be not comparable between the two systems. In Cenchrus, the abscission zone forms very early in inflorescence development as a notch near the base of the primary branch, creating a structural weakness which disintegrates when the seeds are mature, shedding the entire primary branch system, including 1-3 seeds and a number of sterile branchlets. This zone forms so early in development that it was not possible to isolate the region to perform RNAseq. Detailed histological analysis demonstrated that in domesticated pearl millet this zone is thicker, strengthening it and preventing early abscission. Genetic analysis of the offspring of a cross between wild and domesticated pearl millet suggests that there are two QTL involved in shattering, neither of which correspond to QTL for shattering in other species, and the regions that underlie these QTL did not contain SH1 or any other known shattering genes.

Several aspects of the research involved middle and high school science teachers as well as undergraduate students. In the lab, they examined the effects of different hormones and inhibitors on shattering in Setaria, and found strong effects for both auxin and ethylene (mirroring the gene expression data). Students also grew mapping populations of Cenchrus and Setaria, and helped phenotype abscission using force gauge measurements. We also created a teacher workshop, where teachers came to spend a day learning about plants and participating in lesson plans on plant growth that they could take back to the classroom and recreate with their students. We gave them all the materials for these lesson plans, and subsequently published protocols and lesson plans in a teacher education journal. As part of the workshop, we explained the value of plants and their place in both ecosystems and in agriculture, highlighting our work on discovering the genetics of shattering and getting them thinking about both the importance of plants and their value as an experimental organism for classroom learning. In other broader impacts, one of us (Julie Angle) organized the Oklahoma Science and Engineering Fair, in which members of our labs judged entrants.
